choices.text: Screening tests define risk of passing genetic disorder
Screening tests are more accurate than diagnostic tests

questions.text: A genetic counsellor is discussing various types of genetic tests with a couple planning for a child. Which of the following statements accurately describes genetic screening? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Screening tests define risk of passing genetic disorder

 

Genetic screening/testing

 

  • Genetic testing is a type of medical test that identifies changes in genes, chromosomes, or proteins. 
  • It is a process to analyse blood or skin for the systematic search for persons with a particular genotype in a defined population (usually invasive procedures)
  • In order to locate this faulty gene, scientists search for variations in larger pieces of DNA called "markers", latter are found nearby the DNA and become the basis of genetic screening
  • The results of a genetic test can confirm or rule out a suspected genetic condition or help determine a person's chance of developing or passing on a genetic. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Screening tests are more accurate than diagnostic tests: Incorrect. Screening tests assess risk and are not as definitive as diagnostic tests, which provide a precise diagnosis.

 

Option C. Screening requires genetic mapping: Incorrect. Genetic screening does not necessarily involve genetic mapping, which is a detailed analysis of the entire genome.

 

Option D. Involve invasive procedures: Incorrect. Screening tests can often be performed using non-invasive methods such as blood or saliva samples, although some genetic tests may require invasive procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Genetic screening tests are used to define the risk of passing on a genetic disorder and can help determine the likelihood of developing a genetic condition.
  • They are not as definitive as diagnostic tests and do not necessarily involve invasive procedures or genetic mapping.

questions.text: Best level of evidence as seen in research is? [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Meta-analysis

 

  • Meta-analysis represents the highest level of evidence in the evidence-based medicine (EBM) pyramid. 
  • Meta-analysis is defined in a very unique way that is “Analysis of Analyses”- Analysis of multiple studies together. 
  • It is considered the gold standard of evidence-based medicine and is the most superior epidemiological study design.
  • The concept of evidence-based medicine was introduced by D.L. Sackett, who is known as the father of evidence-based medicine. 
  • When organizing studies from the worst to the best in terms of strength of evidence, meta-analysis sits at the top of the EBM pyramid, followed by systematic reviews, randomized control trials (RCTs), cohort studies, case-control studies, cross-sectional studies, ecological studies, then opinion views, animal research, and finally in vitro research at the bottom.


 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cohort study: While cohort studies provide strong evidence and are higher in the EBM pyramid than case-control studies, they are still below meta-analyses and RCTs. Cohort studies follow groups of people over time to determine if exposure to certain factors leads to specific outcomes. They can establish temporality but may have issues with loss to follow-up and are time-consuming.

 

 

Option B. Case control study: These are lower in the EBM hierarchy compared to cohort studies, RCTs, systematic reviews, and meta-analyses. Case-control studies compare cases (people with a condition) with controls (people without the condition) to identify potential risk factors. They are retrospective and subject to recall bias.

 

Option C. RCT (Randomized Control Trial): Though RCTs are considered the gold standard for evaluating interventions and are high in the EBM pyramid, they are still ranked below meta-analyses and systematic reviews. RCTs randomly assign participants to treatment or control groups, minimizing selection bias, but they may not always be generalizable to all populations.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meta-analysis represents the highest level of evidence in the evidence-based medicine hierarchy, above systematic reviews, randomized controlled trials, cohort studies, and case-control studies.

questions.text: Calculate the kappa statistics for the given dataset while comparing the IGRA and Mantoux test. [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 0.4

 

 

The kappa statistic is frequently used to test interrater reliability.

  • In this case, the kappa statistic is 0.4, indicating moderate agreement between the IGRA and Mantoux tests.

questions.text: In the accompanying illustration, a treatment approach for a patient with lymphatic filariasis is depicted. Which type of preventive method is illustrated in this scenario? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Disability limitation

 

  • The image shows an established case of chronic lymphatic filariasis, where hygiene is being maintained to prevent further disability by secondary bacterial infection.
  • Disability limitation is a mode of intervention in tertiary prevention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Specific protection: Health promotion is a mode of intervention in primary prevention, and is the process of enabling people to increase control over, and improve health. Health promotion may be achieved through health education, environmental modification, nutritional interventions or lifestyle changes.

 

Option C. Primary prevention: Primary prevention is a level of prevention which is defined as action taken prior to the onset of a disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur. It is accomplished by measures designed to promote general health and well-being.

 

Option D. Health promotion: Specific protection is a mode of intervention in primary prevention which aims at limiting the number of cases of a particular disease. This includes immunization, use of specific nutrients, chemoprophylaxis, accident protection, and avoidance of allergens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Disability limitation is a mode of tertiary prevention aimed at managing existing disease and preventing further complications, as illustrated in the treatment approach for a patient with chronic lymphatic filariasis in the image.

questions.text: A biostatistics professor is teaching a group of medical students about the fundamentals of statistics. She mentions a branch that is specifically concerned with summarizing and presenting data in a meaningful way. Which of the following branches is she most likely referring to? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Descriptive statistics

 

Descriptive Statistics:

 

  • Data is summarised through the given observations; summarisation is done from a sample of population using parameters such as the mean or standard deviation.
  • Descriptive statistics is a way to organise, represent and describe a collection of data using tables, graphs, and summary measures

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Theoretical statistics: Focuses on the underlying mathematical theory and development of statistical methods, not on data summarization and presentation.

 

Option C. Analytical statistics: This term is less commonly used and does not represent a standard branch of statistics like descriptive or inferential statistics.

 

Option D. Inferential Statistics: Involves using data from a sample to make predictions or inferences about a larger population, including hypothesis testing and confidence intervals.

 

Additional Information

 

Applied Statistics:

 

  • Pure statistics focuses primarily on the numbers, maths, and problems themselves (theoretical)
  • Applied statistics on the other hand, can be thought of as “statistics-in-action” or using statistics with an eye toward real-world problems and what their solutions might be.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Descriptive statistics is dedicated to summarizing and presenting data in an easily understandable way, utilizing tables, graphs, and summary measures.

questions.text: A public health official is reviewing district data to determine which areas should be prioritized for tuberculosis (TB) interventions. According to the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), which of the following HIV-TB prevalence rates would categorize a district as high-priority? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) >10%

 

  • According to the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP), districts are categorized based on specific criteria to prioritize TB interventions.
  • One of these criteria is the prevalence of HIV-TB co-infection.
  • High HIV-TB Prevalence: A district is categorized as high-priority if more than 10% of TB patients tested are known to be HIV positive.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In a village, it is observed that several farmers have crossed gait and use a stick for support to stand up and walk. Due to poor yield from farms, they consume meals containing rice and pulses only. Supplementing their diet with which of the following vitamins could have prevented this? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Vitamin C

 

The given clinical scenario points to diagnosis of neurolathyrism. Vitamin C is beneficial in cases of lathyrism.

 

Lathyrism is of two types:

 

  • Neurolathyrism: In human beings

  • Osteolathyrism (Odoratism): In animals

     

Neurolathyrism is caused by eating the pulse ‘Khesari Dal (Lathyrus sativus)’. Diets containing over 30% of this dal consumed over a period of 2 - 6 months result in neurolathyrism

 

Toxin: present in lathyrus seeds is ‘Beta oxalyl amino alanine’ (BOAA)

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: During your clinical rotation, you notice the different color-coded waste bins meticulously arranged by the nursing staff as per the hospital's waste management protocol. If you were to guide a new intern about the appropriate disposal of items, which item among the following would you instruct them to discard in the black bin? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Glove paper cover

 

  • The paper cover for gloves constitutes regular solid waste, which should be placed in the designated black bin.
  • All types of non-infectious general refuse, including food waste, paper waste, and mineral water bottles, ought to be deposited in the black bins.
  • Bedsheets and linens that are soiled and contaminated with blood or bodily fluids should be appropriately disposed of in the yellow bin.
  • Plastic materials that are recyclable, such as gloves and contaminated gloves, should be placed in the red bins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Soiled linen bedsheet: Should be disposed of in the yellow bin for contaminated waste.

 

Option C. Gloves: Should be placed in the red bin for recyclable materials.

 

Option D. Contaminated gloves: Also go in the red bin for medical waste.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Non-infectious general refuse, such as glove paper covers, should be discarded in the black bin.

questions.text: As per the Factories Act of 1948, what is the maximum permissible weekly working hours, inclusive of overtime? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 60 hours

 

The Factories Act of 1948 permits a maximum of 48 hours of regular work per week, which can be extended up to 60 hours per week with standard overtime.

 

Factories Act – established in 1948:

 

  • Established to include all the factories except Defence, Mining, Railways and Eateries.
  • Per capita space: more than 500/ft3
  • One Safety officer for more than 1000 workers.
  • Children between 14-18 years can be employed only in certain industries and work only between 6 AM-7PM. They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours per day.
  • The maximum working hours for adults should be less than 48 hours per week or less than 9 hours per day.
  • With overtime being included, it should not be more than 60 hours per week.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maximum work hours per week is 48 hours. With overtime one can extend it upto 60 hours.

choices.text: For the prevention of typhoid most important step is immunization
Proper disposal of feces, safe water supply, and personal hygiene is more important than immunization
Resistance to drugs in typhoid is less severe than that of TB
Person to person transmission is present in 10% of cases

questions.text: During a community health education session, an MBBS student is discussing the prevention of Typhoid Fever. Which of the following statements best captures the primary measures for preventing the transmission of Typhoid in the community? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Proper disposal of feces, safe water supply, personal hygiene is more important than immunization

 

  • The control of typhoid fever must be through improved sanitation and domestic/ personal hygiene.
  • Complementary approaches to prevention include immunization which is the only specific preventive measure likely to provide highest benefit for the money spent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. For the prevention of typhoid most important step is immunization: Incorrect. While important, immunization is not the most critical step compared to improving sanitation and hygiene.

 

Option C. Resistance to drugs in typhoid is less severe than that of TB: Incorrect. This statement is unrelated to primary prevention measures for typhoid.

 

Option D. Person to person transmission is present in 10% of cases: Incorrect. Person-to-person transmission is not a significant mode of transmission for typhoid compared to the ingestion of contaminated food or water.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The primary measures for preventing the transmission of Typhoid Fever in the community include proper disposal of feces, a safe water supply, and personal hygiene.
  • These measures are more important than immunization for controlling the spread of the disease.

questions.text: What is the most important assessment based on the treatment given to the patient and their clinical management in a health care facility? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Process

 

Evaluation of "process" can assess a health care facility based on the treatment given to the patient and their clinical management.

 

The process of evaluation involves several steps, such as

 

  • Determining what needs to be evaluated
  • Establishing standards and criteria
  • Planning the methodology
  • Gathering information
  • Analyzing the results
  • Taking action
  • Re-evaluating

 

There are three types of evaluation: structure evaluation, process evaluation, and outcome evaluation.

 

  1. Evaluation of "structure": This is evaluation of whether facilities, equipment, manpower and organization meet a standard accepted by experts as good.
  2. Evaluation of "process": The process of medical care includes the problems of recognition, diagnostic procedures, treatment and clinical management, care and prevention. The way in which the various activities of the programme is carried out is evaluated by comparing with a predetermined standard. An objective and systematic way of evaluating the physician (or nurse) performance is known as "Medical (or nursing) Audit"
  3. Evaluation of "outcome": This is concerned with the end results, that is, whether persons using health services experience measurable benefits such as improved survival or reduced disability. The traditional outcome components are the "5 Ds" of ill-health, viz. disease, discomfort, dissatisfaction, disability and death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Outcome: Focuses on the end results of healthcare, such as improved health status and reduced disease and disability.

 

  • Not Correct: It measures the results of care, not the processes used to deliver it.

 

Option C. Structure: Examines the physical and organizational infrastructure, like facilities, equipment, and staffing.

 

  • Not Correct: It evaluates resources and infrastructure, not the actual delivery of care.

 

Option D. Input: Assesses resources required for healthcare, such as funding, manpower, and materials.

 

  • Not Correct: It looks at the resources used, not how care is delivered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "process" evaluation is the most relevant assessment for determining the quality of treatment and clinical management provided to patients in a healthcare facility. It focuses on the procedures and methods used in patient care, ensuring adherence to established standards and guidelines.

questions.text: An acute encephalitis outbreak has occurred within the community, prompting the initiation of a vaccination campaign. Which of the following is true about the vaccine given in this condition? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Killed and intramuscular

 

Explanation:

 

The question is referring to Japanese Encephalitis (JE) outbreaks, which are not uncommon in India and parts of Southeast Asia. During such outbreaks, emergency vaccination campaigns are often undertaken to control the spread of disease.

 

The most commonly used vaccine in these public health campaigns in India earlier used to be Live JE SA 14-14-2 vaccine (subcutaneous). But nowadays, the inactivated (killed) Vero cell–derived JE vaccine - JENVAC is used intramuscularly.

 

Hence, the correct response based on updated national guidelines is:

 

Killed and intramuscular.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Live and subcutaneous:

While the SA 14-14-2 vaccine is a live, attenuated vaccine given subcutaneously, recent protocols for outbreak settings increasingly prefer killed vaccines like JENVAC, especially in adult populations and for mass campaigns due to ease of storage and safety. Live vaccine SA -14-14-2 is quite good during outbreaks too. But JENVAC has an edge over SA 14-14-2 because of the higher immunity levels it creates with a single dose. Hence, although previously correct, SA 14-14-2 is no longer the preferred or updated answer.

 

Option C) Live and intramuscular:

Live vaccines (like SA 14-14-2) are given subcutaneously. IM route is not used for Live JE SA 14-14-2 routinely.

 

Option D) Killed and subcutaneous:

Killed JE vaccines (like JENVAC or IXIARO) are administered intramuscularly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the setting of a Japanese Encephalitis outbreak, the vaccine currently recommended and used in mass immunization campaigns in India is a killed (inactivated) vaccine administered via the intramuscular route, such as JENVAC. While older guidelines or some regions may have used the live attenuated SA 14-14-2 vaccine given subcutaneously, updated practices now favor the inactivated IM vaccine due to its broader safety profile and compatibility with adult vaccination. Always refer to the most recent national immunization guidelines when answering such public health–related MCQs.

questions.text: All of the options listed can be utilized for assessing data normalcy except? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Mantel-Haenszel test

 

  • The Mantel Haenszel test is used for sample sets that are able to be placed in two by two tables, but unlike the Fisher Exact test and the chi-squared test, there is no “n” requirement.
  • Normality of a data refers to a specific statistical distribution called a normal distribution, or sometimes the Gaussian distribution or bell-shaped curve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plot histogram: Correct for assessing data normalcy. A histogram can visually show whether data follow a normal distribution.

 

Option C. Box whisker: Correct for assessing data normalcy. A box-and-whisker plot (box plot) can reveal the symmetry and spread of data, indicating normality.

 

Option D. Shapiro Wilk test: Correct for assessing data normalcy. The Shapiro-Wilk test is a statistical test specifically designed to test the normality of data.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Mantel-Haenszel test is not used for assessing the normality of data. Normality can be assessed using tools like plot histograms, box-and-whisker plots, Shapiro-Wilk test, Kolmogorov–Smirnov test, etc.

questions.text: A child presented with pharyngitis. A swab was taken from his throat and sent for culture testing. After using the swab, which color-coded bin should it be disposed into? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Yellow

 

Used throat swabs are considered soiled waste, which typically includes items contaminated with blood, body fluids, secretions, and excretions. According to biomedical waste management protocols, such items should be disposed of in yellow bins.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Research is being conducted to find the association between aniline dye exposure and bladder cancer in workers who have worked in the industry for >20 years. Two groups were formed: one directly involved with dye handling and the other group consisting of office clerks not directly exposed to the dye. Years of occupation were noted from records. Then Bladder cancer cases were identified from both the groups in the current time. What type of study is being performed? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Retrospective cohort study

 

The study given here is a retrospective cohort study.

 

A retrospective cohort study is when both the exposure and outcome have occurred before commencing the investigations and study.

 

The given question tells that the workers in the industry were divided into two groups, first are those who are directly exposed and second are clerical staff who are not directly exposed to the suspected carcinogen.

 

The incidence of bladder cancer among these two groups is studied going backward tracking their records. Therefore, it’s a retrospective cohort study.

 

A simple comparison between these studies and an example is shown below:
 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prospective cohort study: Involves following a group over a time span till the development of outcome.

 

Option C. Case-control study: A case-control study involves comparing groups with a specific outcome (cases) with a rather healthy group (controls) and assessing their exposure history. In this case, workers are divided into groups based on their exposure status and the development of bladder cancer.

 

Option D. Intervention and response: Is not a type of epidemiological study design.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A retrospective cohort study involves examining historical data to investigate the relationship between exposure and outcomes. In this scenario, it is used to study the association between aniline dye exposure and bladder cancer among workers over a 20-year period.

questions.text: Which vaccine is administered as part of the immunization program to a 10-year-old school child? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) TT/Td

 

  • Based on the situation provided, a ten-year-old student is recommended to receive the TT/Td vaccine as per the National Immunization Schedule.
  • The Td vaccine is a combination of tetanus and diphtheria vaccines, with a lower concentration of diphtheria antigen, and is recommended for older children and adults.
  • The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW) advises the use of Td vaccine for all age groups, including pregnant women. A dose of 0.5ml is injected into the upper arm muscle. This vaccine is given at the age of 10 and 16.
  • For pregnant women, Td-1 is given early in pregnancy and Td-2 is given 4 weeks after Td-1. A Td booster shot is recommended if a pregnancy occurs within 3 years of the last pregnancy and 2 Td doses were previously received.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NEW National Immunization Schedule (NIS) 2023-24

questions.text: Which disease the girl is related to and what's her name? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Sapna, Leprosy


The girl in the image is named Sapna, and she is associated with the National Leprosy Eradication Program. Sapna is an emblematic figure used to raise awareness about leprosy prevention and control through information, education, and communication (IEC) strategies. She symbolizes the message that leprosy is completely curable. Sapna herself is portrayed as a former leprosy patient who has been fully cured, aiming to reduce stigma and educate the public about the disease's curability.

 

National Leprosy Mission Trust of India is the agency who came out with the concept of the girl Sapna for Leprosy Awareness Efforts Generation.

 

Educational Objective:


Sapna is a character created to promote leprosy awareness and emphasize that leprosy is a 100% curable disease.

questions.text: Which one of the provided thermometers is employed for measuring low air velocity as opposed to the cooling potency of the air? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Kata thermometer 

 

Kata thermometer is used to measure low air velocity rather than the cooling power of the air. It works by measuring the temperature difference between two thin wires heated to different temperatures in a moving air stream. The faster the air moves, the greater the temperature difference between the two wires, allowing the Kata thermometer to measure air velocity.

 

Other Options

Option B. Globe Thermometer: Measures mean radiant temperature, which is the average temperature of all the surfaces surrounding a particular point. This is useful in assessing thermal comfort in environments.

 

Option C. Wet Globe Thermometer: Used to measure heat stress by taking into account temperature, humidity, wind speed, and solar radiation. It is commonly used in the Wet Bulb Globe Temperature (WBGT) index.

Option D. Dial Thermometer: Measures air temperature using a dial indicator. It is a general-purpose thermometer and not specifically designed for measuring air velocity.


Educational Objective:

questions.text: What among the following can be employed for establishing the confidence interval in the Kaplan-Meier survival curve? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Hall-Wellner Band

 

  • The Kaplan-Meier survival curve is a graphical representation commonly used in survival analysis to display the probability of an event, typically survival, over time.
  • It is particularly useful when studying the time to a specific event, such as death or disease progression.
  • The Kaplan-Meier curve often incorporates bands around the survival estimate, which represent the confidence interval.
  • Hall-Wellner bands, Gill bands, and Nair's Equal Precision confidence bands are used for this purpose.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unequal precision band: Not a standard term used for Kaplan-Meier survival curves.

 

Option B. Hirshberg band: Not a recognized method for establishing confidence intervals in Kaplan-Meier survival curves.

 

Option C. Holmes band: Not a recognized method for establishing confidence intervals in Kaplan-Meier survival curves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Hall-Wellner band is employed for establishing the confidence interval in the Kaplan-Meier survival curve, providing a visual representation of the variability and confidence in the survival estimates.

questions.text: Below is the air pollution index chart for four consecutive days at the Delhi station. What is the categorization of the air quality index for November 23rd? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Severe

 

Based on the information provided in the query, the air quality index on November 23rd is measured at 407, falling under the severe category.

 

AIR QUALITY INDEX (AQI)

 

A tool used for effective communication of air quality status on a scale that is easily comprehensible. Complex air quality data of various pollutants are compiled to give a single score (index value), nomenclature and color that determines the air pollution of that particular location.

 

Eight pollutants are taken into consideration to calculate the AQI -

 

  1. PM10 (Airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 10 microns or less)
  2. PM2.5 (Airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 2.5 microns or less)
  3. NO2 (Nitrogen dioxide)
  4. SO2 (Sulfur dioxide)
  5. CO (Carbon monoxide)
  6. 03 (Ozone/Trioxygen)
  7. NH3 (Ammonia)
  8. Pb (Lead)

questions.text: Which of the following pairs is incorrectly matched? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Diagnostic Study - CONSORT

 

  • The reporting standards employed for presenting the outcomes of Randomized Controlled Trials (RCTs) are known as CONSORT, which stands for Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials.
  • CONSORT (Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials) is intended for reporting the outcomes of randomized controlled trials (RCTs), not diagnostic studies.
  • The correct reporting guidelines for diagnostic studies are STARD (Standards for Reporting of Diagnostic Accuracy).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Observational study – MOOSE: MOOSE is Meta-analyses Of Observational Studies in Epidemiology

 

Option B. Systematic review – PRISMA: The Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) statement (2009) helps systematic reviewers transparently report why the review was done, what the authors did, and what they found.

 

Option D. Case report – CARE: The CARE guidelines (for CAse REports) were developed by an international group of experts to support an increase in the accuracy, transparency, and usefulness of case reports.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Note - More reporting guidelines can be found on Equator network

questions.text: A study was undertaken to estimate the effect of a drug ‘D’ in three different groups – Plants, Animals, and Human beings. Samples were chosen randomly out of the three groups individually. This is a type of? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Stratified random sampling

 

Stratified random sampling is a sampling method where the total population is divided into homogeneous subgroups (strata) based on specific characteristics, and then random samples are taken from each stratum. In this question, the total population consists of three different groups: plants, animals, and humans, each forming a distinct stratum. After forming these strata, random sampling is conducted within each group to select samples, ensuring representation from all subgroups.

 

This approach ensures that the study includes balanced and proportional representation of each group, reflecting the actual composition of the population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Simple random sampling: Simple random sampling involves selecting individuals purely by chance from the entire population without dividing it into subgroups. In this scenario, samples are taken from specific groups rather than randomly from the entire population.

 

Option B. Systematic random sampling: This method involves selecting samples from a population at regular intervals (e.g., every nth member). This technique is not used here as the sampling is done within defined groups, not systematically across the whole population.

 

Option D. Cluster random sampling: In cluster sampling, the population is divided into clusters (often geographically or by natural grouping), and entire clusters are randomly selected for study. In this question, the groups (plants, animals, humans) are not clusters but strata, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stratified random sampling involves dividing a heterogeneous population into homogeneous subgroups and then conducting random sampling within each subgroup.

questions.text: Among the following which is considered as water borne hepatitis virus? [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Hepatitis A virus

 

  • Hepatitis A virus (HAV) is considered waterborne because it is primarily transmitted through the fecal-oral route. 
  • Out of the five major types of hepatitis viruses, only Hepatitis A and E are transmitted via the feco-oral route. 
  • This means they can be transmitted through contaminated water and food.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hepatitis B virus: Incorrect because Hepatitis B is not waterborne. Hepatitis B is transmitted through sexual contact, needle syringes, parenteral route, and blood (including blood products). 

 

Option C. Hepatitis C virus: Incorrect because Hepatitis C is not waterborne. It is transmitted through sexual contact, needle sharing, and blood. 

 

Option D. Hepatitis D virus: Incorrect because Hepatitis D is not waterborne. It is transmitted through sexual, parenteral (needles), and blood routes, similar to Hepatitis B and C

 

Educational Objective:

 

Public Health Classification of Water Borne Diseases

questions.text: Where sharp waste can be disposed? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) White container

 

Sharp waste, which includes items like needles, scalpels, and other sharp objects that can puncture or cut, must be disposed of in containers specifically designed to prevent punctures and leaks. These containers are typically white, puncture-resistant, leak-proof, and tamper-proof. This ensures that sharp objects are safely contained to prevent injuries and the spread of infections.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
An internist in India is seeing a patient from a minority cultural and linguistic group. To foster therapeutic alliance and provide the best care possible, which of the following approaches should the physician prioritize? [INICET MAY 2022]

 

  1. Insist on good communication.
  2. Insist on communication only via an interpreter.
  3. Treat them regardless of their cultural perceptions.
  4. Consider the patient's religion and cultural perception.
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 1, 4

 

To foster a strong therapeutic alliance and provide high-quality care, the physician should prioritize the following:

 

1. Insist on good communication: Effective communication is crucial for building a strong doctor-patient relationship. Good communication helps in understanding the patient's concerns, explaining medical conditions and treatment options clearly, and ensuring that the patient feels heard and respected.

 

4. Consider the patient's religion and cultural perception: Culturally competent care involves acknowledging and respecting the patient's cultural, religious, and linguistic background. This approach ensures that care is tailored to meet the specific needs and values of the patient, which can enhance their comfort and trust in the healthcare system.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Insist on communication only via an interpreter: Incorrect. While good communication is essential, insisting on communication only via an interpreter may not always be necessary or preferred by the patient.

 

3. Treat them regardless of their cultural perceptions: Incorrect. Treating patients regardless of their cultural perceptions does not align with providing culturally competent care, which aims to respect and incorporate cultural differences into the care plan.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The communication skills of physicians are an effective step of making effective relationship between doctor and patient
  • Research has shown that the way patients perceive their connection with their physician significantly influences their sense of satisfaction and level of concern about their health
  • The goal of culturally competent health care services is to provide the highest quality of care to every patient, regardless of race, ethnicity, cultural background

questions.text: A young girl has been experiencing repeated instances of yeast infections and respiratory virus infections since she was only 3 months old. Given her immune system's condition, which of the listed vaccines should not be administered to her? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Measles/MMR

 

Based on the information provided, the girl child has a history of recurrent yeast infections and respiratory virus infections since she was 3 months old. This suggests that she may have an underlying immunodeficiency.

 

In this scenario, the measles/MMR vaccine would be contraindicated due to the risk of causing a severe infection in an immunocompromised individual.

 

CONTRAINDICATIONS OF LIVE VACCINES –

 

  • Immunodeficient individuals (Symptomatic HIV infection) except BCG vaccine
  • Immunosuppressed individuals (patient with leukemia or patients on antimetabolites, steroids or radiation)
  • Pregnancy (except Yellow fever)

 

Additional Information

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Killed IPV (Inactivated Polio Vaccine): Safe for immunocompromised individuals as it does not contain live virus.

 

Option C. DPT (Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus): Safe for immunocompromised individuals as it is not a live vaccine.

 

Option D. TT/Td (Tetanus Toxoid/Tetanus and Diphtheria): Safe for immunocompromised individuals as it is not a live vaccine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Live vaccines like Measles/MMR should not be administered to immunocompromised individuals due to the risk of severe infection. Instead, inactivated or subunit vaccines, which do not contain live pathogens, should be used.

questions.text: A lot of patients presented to PHC OPD with edema, ocular problems, cardiac failure. Several deaths were reported too. There was a common history of buying oil from a local grocery store. Drug inspector will use the following test to detect adulteration. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Paper chromatography test

 

The condition described in the question is epidemic dropsy, which is caused by the consumption of mustard oil adulterated with Argemone Mexicana oil. The toxic component of Argemone oil is Sanguinarine, a potent toxin that inhibits the oxidation of pyruvic acid, leading to symptoms such as bilateral non-inflammatory edema, glaucoma, congestive heart failure, and even death.

 

Paper chromatography test is the most sensitive method to detect Argemone oil adulteration in mustard oil, even at extremely low concentrations (0.0001%). This test identifies the presence of Sanguinarine, thus confirming the contamination of the mustard oil with Argemone oil.

 

Other test is - Nitric acid test shows an orange-brown discoloration if Argemone oil is present, requiring a concentration of 0.25% for a positive result.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nitrate test: This option is incorrect. The nitrate test is commonly employed to detect nitrates in water, food, or soil.

 

Option B. Phosphatase test:  This option is incorrect. The phosphatase test is used primarily to determine the pasteurization status of milk, not for detecting oil adulteration.

 

Option D. Sulphuric acid test: This option is incorrect. While sulphuric acid can be used in various tests, it is not the specific test for detecting Argemone oil adulteration in mustard oil.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epidemic dropsy is caused by the consumption of mustard oil adulterated with Argemone Mexicana oil, and the most sensitive test for detecting this adulteration is the paper chromatography test.

choices.text: It is exclusively given in the deltoid
Not given after 7 days of the 1st dose of the vaccine
If human RIG is unavailable, equine is preferred

questions.text: A physician is preparing to administer post-exposure prophylaxis for a patient who has been bitten by a potentially rabid animal. Which of the following statements about the administration of rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) is INCORRECT? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) It is exclusively given in the deltoid

 

  • Dose of Human Rabies Immunoglobulin (HRIg): 20 IU/kg body weight
  • Dose of Equine Rabies Immunoglobulin (ERIg): 40 IU/kg body weight
  • RIg must be given as soon as possible
  • RIg is NOT recommended beyond the 7th day of starting first dose of vaccine
  • RIg must never be given Intravenously
  • Entire dose of RIg (or as much as possible) must be infiltrated around the wound(s) site(s).
  • Remaining dose, if any, must be given Intramuscularly in deltoid

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rabies immunoglobulin (RIG) should be infiltrated around the wound site and any remaining dose given intramuscularly, preferably in the deltoid, but it is not exclusively given in the deltoid.

questions.text: A researcher is examining the relationship between height and weight in a specific population. She decides to utilize a cluster sampling method to streamline the data collection process. After analyzing data from four distinct clusters, each one consistently demonstrates a correlation coefficient of 0.6 between height and weight. Based on this information, what can the researcher expect about the overall correlation coefficient when combining data from all four clusters? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Equal to 0.6

 

  • When each cluster independently shows a correlation coefficient of 0.6 between height and weight, the overall correlation coefficient for the combined data will also be 0.6.
  • This is because the correlation coefficient measures the strength and direction of a linear relationship between two variables, and consistent values across clusters will result in the same overall correlation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SCATTER/DOT DIAGRAM

 

  • Also known as ‘Correlation diagram
  • Is used to depict ‘correlation (relationship) between 2 quantitative variables
  • Vertical axis in scatter diagram: should be the dependent or the outcome variable
  • In a scatter diagram, 2 imaginary lines are drawn along the distribution of dots/ scatter.

questions.text: A study involved 30,000 women who were monitored for a period of 10 years to track the occurrence of breast cancer. Among them, 1200 women developed cancer and were subsequently given a questionnaire to evaluate potential risk factors. In parallel, 2000 women from the same study served as controls and were also subjected to the questionnaire. What is the name of this type of study? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Nested case control

 

  • Given scenario dictates that a population was monitored for development of breast cancer.
  • Out of which, 1200 women developed breast cancer and a small subgroup was taken as control.
  • This study structure points to Nested case control study.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cohort study: Cohort study involves selecting Exposed and non-exposed groups then follow them for development of outcome.

 

Option B. Retrospective cohort: In Retrospective cohort, the outcomes have already occurred before the study begins.

 

Option D. Cross control cohort: Cross control cohort is not a study design.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A nested case-control study involves identifying cases and controls from an existing cohort that is being followed over time, making it a cost-effective way to study the associations between exposures and outcomes.

choices.text: Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, HBV, Injectable Polio
Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, Haemophilus influenza B, Pneumococcal vaccine
Diphtheria, Tetanus, HBV, Haemophilus influenza B, Pertussis

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic for her first round of vaccinations. The mother is anxious and wants to ensure her child receives all the necessary immunizations. You explain that one of the shots the child will receive is the Pentavalent vaccine, which combines five different immunizations into a single injection. Which of the following immunizations are combined in the Pentavalent vaccine? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Diphtheria, Tetanus, HBV, Haemophilus influenza B, Pertussis

 

  • Pentavalent vaccine consists of five vaccines - Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, Hepatitis B and Haemophilus Influenzae Type B (Hib).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

NEW National Immunization Schedule (NIS) 2023-24

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criteria for defining severe acute malnutrition? [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Low Height for age

 

Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) is defined by three specific criteria;

 

  • Weight for height <-3 SD (visible severe wasting)
  • Bilateral pedal edema 
  • Mid-upper arm circumference < 115 millimeters

 

Low height for age is not included in the criteria for defining SAM. Height for age is an indicator of stunting, which reflects chronic malnutrition rather than acute malnutrition. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low height for age (stunting) is an indicator of chronic malnutrition and is not a criterion for defining Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM). 

 

The three criteria for SAM are:

 

  • Weight for height <-3 SD (visible severe wasting)
  • Bilateral pedal edema 
  • Mid-upper arm circumference < 115 millimeters

 

Pem Status Indicators

 

  1. Low Wt. for Age → Under Weight → Acute on chronic PEM
  2. Low Wt. for Height → Wasting → Acute PEM
  3. Low Ht for Age → Stunting → Chronic PEM

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to your clinic for her postpartum checkup. She mentions that she has been exclusively breastfeeding her newborn and is concerned about meeting her own nutritional needs in order to ensure the best for her baby. She asks you about specific nutrient supplementation she might need during this period of lactation. Compared to her pregnancy, which nutrient would you recommend she should pay particular attention to increasing? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Vitamin A

 

  • The requirement for Vitamin A increases during lactation more than during pregnancy.
  • Vitamin A is essential for ensuring the quality of breast milk, which is the sole source of nutrition for a newborn.
  • It plays a critical role in the development of the baby’s immune system and visual function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to the latest Nutritional Guidelines,

 

  • Requirement in Pregnancy > Lactation → Proteins; Zinc; Folic Acid; Iron
  • Requirement in Lactation > Pregnancy → Vitamin A; Iodine; Vitamin C; Carbohydrates, Calcium
  • Requirement in Pregnancy = Lactation → Vitamin D; Calcium

questions.text: Under MTP Act of India, for cases of MTP after 24 weeks POG, there has to be a Medical board to advise. It comprises of all except: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Legal advisor


Under the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act of India, a Medical Board must be constituted for termination of pregnancy beyond 24 weeks, specifically in cases of substantial fetal anomalies. This board plays a crucial role in evaluating the circumstances and approving the procedure when necessary. The Medical Board is required to have specific members to provide expert medical advice, including:

 

  1. An Obstetrician-Gynaecologist who provides expertise on maternal and fetal health.
  2. A Radiologist who is crucial for diagnosing fetal anomalies through imaging.
  3. A Paediatrician who offers insights into the potential viability and health of the fetus.
  4. Members nominated by state government in official Gazette

 

These experts collectively evaluate the condition to ensure a medically sound decision. However, the board does not include a legal advisor, as their role is primarily medical, focusing on the health aspects rather than legal counsel.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The Medical Board for MTP cases beyond 24 weeks includes an Obstetrician-Gynaecologist, Radiologist, and Paediatrician but does not include a legal advisor.

questions.text: A biostatistician is reviewing data from a recent research study. She observes that the confidence interval (CI) for one of the primary outcomes is quite wide. Which of the following factors is least likely to contribute to the widening of the confidence interval? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Increasing sample size

 

A confidence interval (CI) provides a range of values within which we can be reasonably certain that the population parameter lies. The width of the CI can be influenced by several factors:

 

  • Increase in sample size: As the sample size increases, the margin of error decreases, resulting in a narrower confidence interval. Therefore, an increase in sample size is least likely to contribute to the widening of the CI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decrease in sample size: A smaller sample size increases the margin of error, leading to a wider confidence interval. This is because with fewer observations, there is more uncertainty about the estimate.

 

Option C. Increase in variability: Higher variability in the data increases the margin of error, which in turn widens the confidence interval. Variability affects the precision of the estimate.

 

Option D. Increase in confidence level: Increasing the confidence level (e.g., from 95% to 99%) requires a larger range to ensure that the true population parameter is captured with greater certainty, thus widening the confidence interval.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A smaller sample size or a higher variability will result in a wider confidence interval with a larger margin of error
  • As sample size increases, the margin of error decreases
  • As the variability in the population increases, the margin of error increases
  • As you increase the confidence level (e.g., 95% to 99%) while holding the sample size and variability constant, the confidence interval widens
  • Smaller the SD, narrower is Confidence interval

questions.text: A laboratory technician is analyzing cell populations using flow cytometry. This technique allows for the simultaneous multiparametric analysis of the physical and/or chemical characteristics of single cells flowing through an optical and/or electronic detection apparatus. Which visual depictions are commonly generated in flow cytometry for the evaluation of these cell populations? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Histogram, dot plot

 

  • Histogram and Dot plot can be used to depict flow cytometry analysis.
  • Histogram can be used to compare single parameter (1D)

 

 

 Scatter/Dot plot are used to compare 2 or 3 parameters (2D; 3D)

 

 

Flow Cytometry is used to detect and measure physical and chemical characteristics of a population of cells or parameters like cell counting, sorting, detect microorganisms, detect neoplasm and various more.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In flow cytometry, histograms and dot plots are the common visual depictions for evaluating cell populations.

questions.text:
The table provided illustrates a multivariate analysis assessing the relationship between the risk of blindness and various factors including age, literacy rate, place of residence, and gender. Which of the subsequent statements accurately interprets this data? [INICET MAY 2022]

 

 

  1. Female population is at greater risk of developing blindness.
  2. People dwelling in rural areas are at increased risk of developing blindness.
  3. Risk of developing blindness increases with age.
  4. Illiteracy leads to increased risk of developing blindness.
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 3 and 4

 

  • The correct statements drawn from the values given in the table are 3 and 4.
  • An odds ratio is a measure of the association between an exposure and an outcome. It represents the odds that an outcome will occur given a particular exposure in comparison to the odds of the outcome occurring in the absence of that exposure.

 

Statement 3: Risk of developing blindness increases with age.

 

  • Correct. The odds ratios increase with age categories, and all are statistically significant with p-values <0.001. This indicates that the risk of developing blindness increases with age.

 

Statement 4: Illiteracy leads to increased risk of developing blindness.

 

  • Correct. The odds ratio for illiteracy is 1.2 with a p-value <0.01, indicating that illiteracy is associated with an increased risk of developing blindness.

 

Other Options:

 

Statements 1 and 2 have an odds ratio of >1 and a statistically significant p-value, respectively. This implies that the cause increases the risk of disease and is a risk factor. However, these statements are incorrect due to the following reason: -

 

Statement 1: Female population is at greater risk of developing blindness is a false statement; since the odds ratio is <1, the female population will be at lesser risk of developing blindness than the male population.

 

Statement 2: People dwelling in rural areas are at increased risk of developing blindness is also false; a p-value of >0.05 means that this association is not statistically significant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Odds ratio interpretation:

 

  • Odds ratio of 1: Indicates that the risk factor is not related to the disease.
  • Odds ratio less than 1: Indicates that a person with the disease is less likely to have been exposed to the factor, implying that the factor may be protective.
  • Odds ratio greater than 1: Indicates that the factor is associated with an increased risk of the disease.

 

p-value interpretation:

 

  • p-value < 0.05: Indicates that the result is statistically significant.
  • p-value > 0.05: Indicates that the result is not statistically significant.

choices.text: Collect using your hand and discard in drain
Collect using paper/cardboard and put in water tube/bucket
Collect and throw outside in the environment
Broom it and discard in dustbin

questions.text: A medical student accidentally drops a sphygmomanometer, causing mercury spill on the floor. What is the most appropriate method to manage this spill? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Collect using paper/cardboard and put in water tube/bucket

 

  • Identify visible larger mercury beads and push together using Cardboards and collect using Syringe without needle.
  • Store collected mercury beads in an air tight plastic bag and label it properly. Put all the items that were used to pick up the mercury, including index cards or cardboard, eyedropper, contaminated tape, paper towels, and zipper-type bags into the trash bag. Carefully seal the trash bag that contains the mercury contaminated waste and dispose them properly.
  • Do not use a vacuum, broom or paint brush to clean up the spill. These methods can spread the mercury to other areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most appropriate method to manage a mercury spill is to collect it using paper/cardboard and place it in a water tube or bucket, then ensure safe and proper disposal.
  • Avoid direct contact, vacuuming, or sweeping the mercury.

choices.text: Mode is affected by extreme values
Mean is affected by extreme values
Median is calculated by overall observations
Mode can be used as a qualitative data descriptor

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false for descriptors of central tendency? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Mode is affected by extreme values

 

  • Extreme values in a given dataset do not influence the mode.
  • Mode is the most frequent or most commonly occurring value in a distribution.
  • It is uninfluenced by extreme values and can be used to describe qualitative data

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mean is affected by extreme values: This is true. Extreme values (outliers) can significantly affect the mean, making it an unreliable measure of central tendency in skewed distributions.

 

Option C. Median is calculated by overall observations: This is true. The median is determined by arranging all observations in order and finding the middle value, or the average of the two middle values if the number of observations is even.

 

Option D. Mode can be used as a qualitative data descriptor: This is true. The mode is applicable to qualitative data as it represents the most frequently occurring category or value.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The mode is not affected by extreme values and can be used to describe qualitative data.
  • In contrast, the mean is affected by extreme values, and the median is a robust measure of central tendency that is calculated using overall observations.

questions.text: What among the options serves as a factor that conditions to the development of malnutrition? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Infectious diseases

 

Infectious diseases act as conditioning influences that contribute to the development of malnutrition. They can exacerbate malnutrition by increasing morbidity, leading to decreased food intake, loss of nutrients, anorexia, and overall growth failure, which in turn lowers immunity and creates a vicious cycle of poor health.

 

Other 3 Options are not considered as a conditioning influence.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Cervical Pap smear in a 40-year-old patient
Neonatal screening of a new-born baby for hypothyroidism
Screening of immigrants to a country
Urine for sugar screening in a 40-year-old man

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of prospective screening? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Screening of immigrants to a country

 

Prospective screening is conducted primarily for the benefit of the community or the public health system, rather than for the direct benefit of the individual being screened. It aims to control the spread of diseases and protect public health by identifying potential carriers of infectious diseases or individuals with certain health conditions that may pose a risk to others.

 

Screening of immigrants to a country: This is a classic example of prospective screening. It is done to detect infectious diseases or other health conditions in immigrants to prevent the spread of disease and protect the health of the population in the host country. This screening is often mandated by public health authorities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical Pap smear in a 40-year-old patient:  This is an example of prescriptive screening, as it is conducted for the individual's benefit to detect cervical cancer early.

 

Option B. Neonatal screening of a new-born baby for hypothyroidism:  This is also an example of prescriptive screening aimed at early detection and management of hypothyroidism in newborns.

 

Option D. Urine for sugar screening in a 40-year-old man:  This is another example of prescriptive screening, used to detect diabetes in the individual.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Rapid diagnostic test (HRP Type 2 Pf Antigen)

questions.text: Malaria diagnosis under field settings is best done by using? [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Thick peripheral blood smear

 

  • The mainstay of malaria diagnosis in India is smear microscopy. Research studies have demonstrated that the sensitivity of thick smear is greater than that of thin smear. 
  • Thick smear provides sensitivity for detecting the presence of malaria, while thin smear is used for species identification, offering specificity to the test. 
  • Although PCR is the most sensitive test overall, we are considering field settings in a developing country like India, where cost is a significant factor.
  • Thick peripheral blood smear has low cost compared to rapid diagnostic kits and is therefore the best possible test for field settings in India.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thin peripheral blood smear: This is less sensitive than thick smear for detecting the presence of malaria parasites. Thin smear is primarily used for species identification once malaria has been detected. 

 

Option C. Buffy coat technique: This technique is not commonly used in field settings for malaria diagnosis. It requires more sophisticated laboratory equipment and technical expertise which may not be available in field conditions.

 

Option D. Rapid diagnostic kit (HRP Type 2 Pf Antigen): Rapid diagnostic kits based on histidine-rich protein type 2 have moderate cost compared to smear microscopy. Additionally, they can only detect Plasmodium falciparum, whereas all four subtypes of malaria are present in India. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

For malaria diagnosis in field settings in developing countries like India, thick peripheral blood smear is the preferred method due to its higher sensitivity and lower cost compared to other methods.

questions.text: The blood pressure of a population was tracked from childhood to adulthood. It was observed that those who had lower BP in childhood had low BP in adulthood, while those who had higher BP in childhood had high BP in adulthood. This can be best described as [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Tracking of blood pressure

 

The phenomenon described in the question is known as tracking of blood pressure. This term refers to the tendency for individuals to maintain their relative position within a distribution of blood pressure values over time. Essentially, individuals with lower blood pressure in childhood tend to have lower blood pressure in adulthood, and those with higher blood pressure in childhood tend to have higher blood pressure in adulthood.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rule of halves: This concept refers to the observation that about half of those with hypertension are aware of their condition, half of those aware are treated, and half of those treated are adequately controlled. It is not directly related to the tracking phenomenon described.

 

 

Option C. The WHO STEPwise approach: approach to surveillance (STEPS) is an internationally comparable, standardized and integrated surveillance tool through which countries can collect, analyse and disseminate core information on noncommunicable diseases (NCDs).

 

Option D. Primordial approach: Primordial prevention refers to measures taken to prevent the development of risk factors in a population, thereby reducing the overall incidence of disease. This concept is related to preventing the onset of risk factors and diseases, rather than tracking existing conditions over time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tracking of blood pressure describes the observation that individuals maintain their relative position within a distribution of blood pressure values from childhood to adulthood. This means that blood pressure levels tend to remain consistent relative to peers over time.

questions.text: What does the provided formula correspond to? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Standard deviation

 

  • Standard deviation is the Root of Mean od Squares of Deviations

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Variance: Variance = (Standard deviation)2

 

Option C. Mean: Mean is obtained as sum of all values divided by the number of values in the distribution. It is not affected by extreme values.

 

Option D. Median: Median is the middle most value in a distribution arranged in an ascending or descending order of values.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The standard deviation measures the dispersion of a data set around its mean.

questions.text:
A pediatrician is reviewing mortality trends among children aged between 1-4 years based on verbal autopsy reports from the years 2010-2013. She wants to educate parents on the primary causes of death to improve preventive measures in her community. From the list provided below, which sequence correctly represents the leading causes of death in a descending order for this age group? [INICET MAY 2021]

 

  1. Diarrhea
  2. Pneumonia
  3. Malaria
  4. Injuries
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 2>1>4>3

 

  • According to the verbal autopsy report of 2010-2013, leading cause of death among 1–4-year-old children in a developing country like India in descending order is Pneumonia > Diarrhea > Injuries > Malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 In a developed country, leading causes of death are:

 

  1. Accident injury
  2. Congenital anomaly
  3. Neoplasms
  4. Influenza
  5. Pneumonia

questions.text: You're a clinician in a busy urban sexual health clinic, and it's been a hectic day with multiple patients presenting with sexually transmitted infections (STIs). The STI treatment kits are color-coded for efficient management, but the new nurse seems a bit overwhelmed with the options. You decide to guide her. Based on the clinical presentation, which color-coded STI kit would you suggest for the following symptoms? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) A-4, B-1, C-3, D-2

 

A. Lower abdominal pain:

 

  • Correct Kit: Yellow, Kit 6, which includes Cefixime, Metronidazole, and Doxycycline, specifically designed to manage symptoms like lower abdominal pain, which can be associated with pelvic inflammatory disease or other related conditions.

 

B. Urethral discharge:

 

  • Correct Kit: Grey, Kit 1, which contains Azithromycin and Cefixime. This kit is ideal for treating symptoms like urethral discharge, which can indicate infections such as gonorrhea or chlamydia.

 

C. Non-herpetic genital ulcer:

 

  • Correct Kit: White, Kit 3, equipped with Azithromycin and Penicillin, suitable for treating non-herpetic genital ulcers, often caused by syphilis or chancroid.

 

D. Vaginal discharge:

 

  • Correct Kit: Green, Kit 2, which contains Secnidazole and Fluconazole, tailored for treating vaginal discharge that could be due to bacterial vaginosis or yeast infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The National Aids Control Organization (NACO has provided color-coded kits for the syndromic management of sexually transmitted diseases:

questions.text: The vector shown in the image below transmits which of the following organism? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Orientia tsutsugamushi

 

  • The picture depicts a trombiculid mite, known for transmitting Orientia tsutsugamushi.

 

SCRUB TYPHUS (ORIENTIA)

 

  • Caused by → Orientia tsutsugamushi
  • Vector → Trombiculid mites (Leptotrombidium)
  • Chiggerosis → Among all stages of mite, larvae (called chiggers) are only stage that feed on humans. Hence, scrub typhus is also called chiggerosis.
  • Clinical manifestations
    • Eschar (at the site of bite)
    • Regional lymphadenopathy
    • Maculopapular rash
  • DOC → Doxycycline

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kyasanur forest disease: Kyasanur forest disease is vector borne disease caused by hard tick.

 

 

Option C. Chandipura virus: Chandipura virus is vector borne disease transmitted by sandfly

 

 

Option D. Anaplasma: Anaplasma is a tick-borne disease affecting ruminants, dogs, and horses, and is caused by Anaplasma bacteria. Mainly transmitted by Ixodes ticks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The trombiculid mite, particularly in its larval stage called a chigger, transmits Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus.

questions.text: In the context of the health belief model, a medical student is reviewing its different components. One of the boxes, labeled "C", is described as the individual's willingness to act on their beliefs regarding health threats and the benefits of taking preventive action. Which of the following best represents box C? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Health motivation

 

  • Box C stands for health motivation.
  • This represents the individual's readiness and willingness to engage in health-promoting behaviors.
  • This motivation influences how individuals perceive their susceptibility and severity of health issues, as well as the benefits and barriers to taking action.

 

 

The health belief model was proposed from the idea that a person's health behaviour changes in accordance with certain beliefs.

 

It can be categorized as follows:

 

  • Individual perceptions.
  • Variable factors that modify beliefs.
  • Action.

 

Individual perceptions:

 

Perceived susceptibility refers to a person's own beliefs about the probability of developing a disease. If the perceived susceptibility is high, an individual is more likely to engage in health-promoting behaviour to reduce the chances of contracting the illness.

 

Perceived severity is an individual's assessment of the severity of a particular health problem. If the disease is perceived to have a high severity, then the person is more likely to adopt a healthier lifestyle. Perceived threat comprises perceived susceptibility and severity. People with a higher perceived threat tend to take on health-promoting activities.

 

Action:

 

Perceived benefits refer to a person's subjective judgment on how a particular health habit is modifying his chances of developing a disease. If the person believes that a habit is likely to reduce his/her chances of susceptibility to a disease or lower the severity of a disease, he/she is more likely to follow that healthy habit.

 

Perceived barriers to action also influence if a person wants to follow healthy behaviour. The benefits of a particular health habit must overweigh the barriers that a person must overcome to continue following that behaviour.

 

Cues to action may be internal or external. Internal cues include pain and clinical symptoms. External cues include awareness through media, physicians, and friends.

 

The health belief system is thought to be useful in analyzing health behaviour patterns and formulating disease prevention plans based on these beliefs. All internal and external factors, including demographic and psychological characteristics, aim at health motivation to attain the action phase of a health belief system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perceived control: Perceived control refers to a person's internal belief in the control they would have over things that are part of the past or the future or over a process, behavior, and outcome. Perceived control can influence all of the categories of the health belief system.

 

Option B. Behavioral modification: Behavioral modification is part of the action after assessing all of the above-mentioned concepts.

 

Option D. Self-efficacy: Self-efficacy can be defined as a person's capacity in achieving his health goals. A person's confidence in his/her ability to overcome limitations to attain his/her health goals was found to be a major factor in determining the outcome of his behavioral changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the health belief model, health motivation (Box C) represents an individual's willingness to act on their health beliefs regarding susceptibility, severity, benefits, and barriers to take preventive health actions.

questions.text: What importance does the point labelled as 'C' hold? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Onset of symptoms

 

  • The given image depicts timeline of natural history of disease in an individual over time, in which the point labelled C denotes the onset of symptoms.

 

 

 

  • Natural history of disease describes the natural course of the disease from its early pre pathogenesis phases to termination.
