  • The onset of symptoms marks the transition from the subclinical stage to the clinical stage of disease.

questions.text: Which of the options was initiated to ensure complete immunization of children? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Mission Indradhanush

 

Mission Indradhanush was launched in 2014 by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare to ensure complete immunization of children who are either partially immunized or completely unimmunized by 2020. Later, it was modified in 2017 as Intensified Mission Indradhanush to achieve the same goal by December 2018, including 12 vaccine-preventable diseases. The program involves 4 rounds of immunization held for 7 days each month, and it replaced the previous focus on 7 diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MISSION INDRADHANUSH INCLUDES

 

  1. Polio
  2. Diphtheria
  3. Pertussis
  4. Tetanus
  5. TB
  6. Measles
  7. Hepatitis B
  8. Rota Virus
  9. MR
  10. IPV
  11. JE
  12. HiB
  13. PCV

questions.text: During a health education session, people cannot understand your few technical words during the chat, and it’s a miscommunication. This is which type of barrier? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Semantic barrier


A semantic barrier, also known as a linguistic barrier, arises when there is a difference in language or when technical jargon and complex terms are used that the audience cannot understand. This leads to miscommunication because the message is not clearly conveyed. In the given scenario, the use of technical words during the health education session caused a communication breakdown because the audience did not understand those terms. This is a classic example of a semantic barrier.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cultural barrier: A cultural barrier occurs when differences in customs, beliefs, caste or religion prevent effective communication. This is not the case here as the issue was related to language and technical terms, not cultural differences.

 

Option B. Physiological barrier: Physiological barriers include physical issues like hearing difficulties or speech impairments that obstruct communication. These are not relevant to the scenario described, where language misunderstanding was the primary issue.

 

Option C. Psychological barrier: Psychological barriers stem from emotional disturbances, stress, or mental conditions that hinder effective communication. While these can affect communication, they are unrelated to the miscommunication caused by technical words in this example.

 

Educational Objective:


A semantic barrier occurs when the use of complex language, technical terms, or unfamiliar words leads to misunderstanding and miscommunication.

choices.text: Urgent referral to the tertiary care centre immediately
Administer IV antibiotics and ask the patient to be brought after 24 hours

questions.text: A 2-year-old toddler with a weight of 11 kg was brought to the pediatric outpatient department. The child exhibited a respiratory rate of 38 breaths per minute and upon examination, noticeable chest indrawing was detected. What is the next step of management? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Oral amoxicillin for five days

 

According to the latest revised guidelines by WHO, the management of childhood pneumonia has been updated based on new evidence. In the given scenario, a 2-year-old child presents with a respiratory rate of 38 breaths per minute and chest indrawing, which fits the criteria for pneumonia but without general danger signs. According to the revised classification, the appropriate management for this case is oral amoxicillin for five days and home care advice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urgent referral to the tertiary care centre immediately: This is recommended for children showing general danger signs or very severe disease, not for pneumonia with chest indrawing without other danger signs.

 

Option C. Administer IV antibiotics and ask the patient to be brought after 24 hours: This would be applicable for severe cases requiring inpatient care, not for managing a case of pneumonia without general danger signs at an outpatient department.

 

Option D. Start antipyretics urgently: While antipyretics may be used to manage fever, they do not address the underlying pneumonia and are not the primary management step in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Percentage of undernourished children under 5 years

questions.text: Which of these options is not part of the Global Hunger Index (GHI)? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Infant mortality rate

 

  • Infant mortality rate is not a component of the global hunger index (GHI).
  • The three components of the GHI are - 
    • Inadequate food supply [PNU – Undernourished Population]
    • Child mortality (under the age of 5) [U5M – Under 5 Mortality]
    • Malnutrition (wasting, stunting) [CUW – Child underweight]

 

The GHI is a tool used to measure and track hunger at global, regional, and national levels.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Global Hunger Index (GHI) does not include the infant mortality rate. It focuses on inadequate food supply, child mortality under the age of five, and child undernutrition as its key components to assess hunger and malnutrition.

choices.text: If replacement feeding, the neonate should be tested for HIV, if negative, ART is not required.
In exclusive breastfeeding, give nevirapine for 6 months only when baby is positive
If replacement feeding, the neonate need not receive nevirapine if HIV negative
If exclusive replacement feeding, give nevirapine for 6 weeks, even if the baby is negative

questions.text: A pediatrician is providing counselling to a pregnant woman who is HIV positive about postnatal care for her soon-to-be-born child. Which of the following statements best captures the recommended management for an infant born to a mother with HIV regarding antiretroviral treatment (ART)? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) If exclusive replacement feeding, give nevirapine for 6 weeks, even if the baby is negative

 

The baby should be given prophylaxis irrespective of feeding status and HIV status at birth.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. If replacement feeding, the neonate should be tested for HIV, if negative, ART is not required: Incorrect. Prophylaxis with nevirapine should still be given for 6 weeks regardless of HIV status.

 

Option B. In exclusive breastfeeding, give nevirapine for 6 months only when baby is positive: Incorrect. Nevirapine is given as prophylaxis irrespective of the infant's HIV status.

 

Option C. If replacement feeding, the neonate need not receive nevirapine if HIV negative: Incorrect. Prophylaxis should still be provided for 6 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Infants of HIV-positive mothers on exclusive replacement feeding get 6-week nevirapine, regardless of their HIV status.

questions.text: A bubonic outbreak has occurred within the community. What is the responsible vector for this condition? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Xenopsylla cheopis

 

Xenopsylla cheopis, commonly known as a rat flea, serves as the carrier for the bubonic plague. This particular flea species can be recognized by its distinctive conical-shaped head, along with a thorax, abdomen, and three sets of legs.


 

  • Plague is a zoonotic disease caused by Yersinia pestis.
  • The reservoir of infections is wild rodents.
  • Humans acquire the disease by the bite of an infected flea, by direct contact with the tissues of the infected animal, or by droplet infection from cases of pneumonic plague.
  • Human plague mainly presents as:

 

 

Bubonic plague- This is the most common type of disease. There is fever along with painful lymphadenitis. Within a few days, the lymph nodes in the groin, axilla, or neck enlarge and are called buboes. This is followed by the suppuration of the buboes.

 

Pneumonic plague- It develops as a complication of bubonic-septicemic plague.

 

Septicemic plague- It occurs when the infection spreads to blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Species Phlebotomus argentipes: belongs to the group of sand fly. It transmits kala azar. Other diseases transmitted by sand flies are sandfly fever and oriental sore.

 

Option C. Ixodes Tick: transmits Lyme’s disease caused by Borrelia burgdorferi.

 

Option D. Female Anopheles mosquito transmits malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Xenopsylla cheopis (rat flea) is the primary vector responsible for transmitting the bubonic plague, caused by Yersinia pestis. Understanding the vector and transmission routes is crucial for controlling and preventing outbreaks.

questions.text: The floods had an impact on Kerala's Pathanamthitta district, leading the government to provide doxycycline tablets for prophylaxis. What other chemical is set to be distributed in conjunction with this? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Zinc phosphide

 

Explanation - 

 

The government distributed doxycycline tablets for prophylaxis following floods in Kerala to prevent the spread of diseases such as leptospirosis, acute diarrheal diseases, and dengue.

  • Leptospirosis, which is caused by contaminated water with rodent urine, can be prevented by chemoprophylaxis with Doxycycline, using rubber shoes and gloves, anti-rodent measures, and establishing a proper drainage system.
  • Zinc phosphide is used for chemical control of rodents due to its good safety record, low cost and high effectiveness
  • Chlorine tablets and bleaching powder are used to disinfect household water supply. Insecticides and larvicides like abate are used for indoor residual sprays for drinking water.
  • General hygiene and sanitary measures must also be followed to control the spread of diseases during floods.

questions.text: A clinician is attending to several patients with different conditions in a hospital setting. Which of the following diseases necessitates placing the patient in a separate isolation room due to its airborne transmission risk? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Measles

 

Measles is a highly contagious viral disease that spreads primarily through the air via respiratory droplets from coughs or sneezes of infected individuals. Its high transmissibility requires that patients be isolated in airborne infection isolation rooms to prevent the spread of the virus to others, particularly the unvaccinated or immunocompromised individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rabies: Transmitted through the bite or scratch of an infected animal, rabies does not require airborne isolation as it is not spread through the air.

 

Option C. Nipah: While Nipah virus can be transmitted from person to person, it is primarily spread through direct contact with infected bats, pigs, or other Nipah-infected individuals' body fluids. Airborne transmission is not the primary mode.

 

Option D. Aseptic meningitis: Generally caused by viral infections and not considered highly contagious through the air. Transmission is typically through direct contact with an infected person's respiratory secretions or feces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Measles necessitates isolation in an airborne infection isolation room due to its high potential for airborne transmission, making it critical to prevent its spread in healthcare settings.

questions.text: A 30-week primigravida c/o reduced vision at night. She has been avoiding papaya, mango, and other fruits throughout her pregnancy as she thinks they could be abortifacients. It is the primary duty of which of the following workers to provide counselling and information to the patient? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) AWW

 

The described scenario involves a pregnant woman with a misconception about the consumption of certain fruits during pregnancy and a symptom of night blindness, which could indicate a deficiency in Vitamin A. The Anganwadi Worker (AWW) is primarily responsible for providing health and nutrition education and counselling to mothers, which includes information about proper dietary practices during pregnancy. AWWs are trained to address specific local challenges that prevent healthy behaviors, such as cultural practices, myths, local food availability, and dietary practices.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ANM (Auxiliary Nurse Midwife): ANMs primarily focus on providing basic medical care, immunizations, and assisting with childbirth and antenatal care. While they do offer some nutritional advice, the specific role of counselling about dietary misconceptions primarily falls under the AWW.

 

Option C. Trained birth attendant: Trained birth attendants are primarily involved in assisting with childbirth and ensuring safe delivery practices. Their role does not typically include extensive nutritional counselling.

 

Option D. ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist): ASHAs work to promote community health and link the community with health services. They play a supportive role in health education, but detailed nutritional counselling is more specifically the responsibility of the AWW.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It is the duty of the Anganwadi Worker (AWW) to provide health and nutrition education and counselling to pregnant women, addressing misconceptions about diet and ensuring they receive proper nutritional guidance. Their training includes addressing local challenges and cultural practices to promote healthy behaviors.

questions.text: ICER is used as an Economic model in which of the following Health Management Techniques: [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Cost effectiveness analysis

 

ICER stands for Incremental Cost-Effectiveness Ratio. It is a measure used in cost-effectiveness analysis to compare the differences in cost between two interventions relative to the differences in their effectiveness or results. The formula for calculating ICER is:

 

ICER = (C₁ - C₀) / (E₁ - E₀)

 

Where:

 

  • C₁ and E₁ represent the cost and effectiveness of the intervention being evaluated
  • C₀ and E₀ represent the cost and effectiveness of the control or comparison intervention

 

ICER is primarily used in cost-effectiveness analysis when comparing treatment alternatives, especially when expressed in terms of quality-adjusted life years (QALYs). It helps decision-makers determine if the additional cost of a more effective intervention is worth the additional benefit gained.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cost benefit analysis: This is incorrect because cost-benefit analysis expresses both costs and benefits in monetary terms, whereas ICER is used in cost-effectiveness analysis where effectiveness is measured in non-monetary outcomes (like life years gained or QALYs).

 

Option C. Systems analysis: This is incorrect because systems analysis is a problem-solving approach that involves comparing alternative cost-effective solutions in a health program. 

 

Option D. Cost accounting: This is incorrect because cost accounting deals with the basic cost structure of a health program and the allocation of resources. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

ICER (Incremental Cost-Effectiveness Ratio) is a key economic model used in cost-effectiveness analysis to compare the relative costs and outcomes of different interventions.

questions.text: What is the SI unit used to measure the brightness of light from a point source among the options provided? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Candela

 

The candela is the SI unit used to measure the brightness (luminous intensity) of a light source emitting light in a specific direction. It quantifies the amount of light emitted from a point source within a solid angle of one steradian.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lux: Usage: Measures illumination or illuminance.

 

  • Definition: It quantifies the amount of light reaching a surface. One lux is equal to one lumen per square meter.

 

Option C. Lambert: Usage: Measures brightness or luminance.

 

  • Definition: It quantifies the amount of light emitted by a surface. One lambert is equal to the luminance of a surface emitting or reflecting one lumen per square centimeter.

 

Option D. Lumen: Usage: Measures luminous flux.

 

  • Definition: It quantifies the total amount of visible light emitted by a source. One lumen is the luminous flux emitted within a solid angle of one steradian by a point source with a luminous intensity of one candela.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: At the Urban Primary Health Centre (U-PHC), you are in charge of managing hypertension clinic services. You have 50 patients transferred from another healthcare unit for hypertension management; 40 of these patients are prescribed amlodipine (5mg, daily) and 10 are on lisinopril (10mg, daily) due to contraindications with amlodipine. Considering the need for continuous treatment and potential increases in patient numbers, calculate the number of tablets needed for the next month and determine the appropriate reorder factor. [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 3000, rf=2

 

Calculation -  

 

Requirement of Amlodipine

 

40 patients x 1 Tablet per day x 30 Days = 1200 Tablets

 

Requirement of Lisinopril

 

10 patients x 1 Tablet per day x 30 Days = 300 Tablets

 

Reorder factor (Rf) for drugs supplied every:

 

  • 1 Month - 2
  • 3 Months - 6
  • 6 Months – 12

 

For the given question,

 

Total of 1500 tablets are required and reorder factor is 2

 

Hence, Total tablets required = (1200 + 300) x 2 = 3000 Tablets

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Reorder Factor (rf): A reorder factor of 2 is commonly used for monthly resupply scenarios to account for unexpected increases in patient count or dosage adjustments, ensuring no interruption in patient care.

questions.text: After a road traffic accident case has been admitted, there is a blood spillage on the hospital floor. Which type of disinfectant would you select for cleaning the floor? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Sodium hypochlorite

 

If there is spillage of blood on the hospital floor, sodium hypochlorite is the recommended disinfectant for cleaning the floor.

 

Procedure to be followed in the event of blood/body fluid spillage:

 

  1. Wear a pair of non-sterile gloves
  2. Broken glass (if any) of the container is cleaned first using tongs or a pan and brush and discarded in the sharp container. Caution is taken to not use hands.
  3. Disposable paper towels are used to absorb as much as possible.
  4. Water and detergent are used to clean the surface until visibly clean.
  5. The area is saturated with 0.5% Sodium Hypochlorite. This is prepared by diluting 5.25% sodium hypochlorite bleach at a 1:10 ratio.
  6. The tongs, pan, and brush are washed under running water and left to dry
  7. The gloves are removed and discarded.
  8. Hands are washed with soap and water using proper technique and dried with a disposable towel.
  9. The spillage is recorded in an incident book.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ethyl alcohol: Is not recommended for cleaning surfaces with blood spills as it is less effective against some microorganisms and may evaporate too quickly.

 

Option B. Chlorhexidine: is also less effective against blood-borne pathogens and is better suited for skin disinfection.

 

Option D. Formaldehyde: Is not commonly used as a disinfectant due to its potential health hazards.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For effective disinfection of surfaces contaminated with blood spills, sodium hypochlorite is the preferred choice due to its broad-spectrum antimicrobial activity and ability to neutralize blood-borne pathogens.

choices.text: Diet should contain 400 kcal from carbohydrates
Diet should contain 800 kcal from fat

questions.text: What does the FDA say about a diet, high in fat intake? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Diet should contain total 1000 kcal

 

  • According to FDA, high fat diet is a diet having 50% of total caloric content of the meal and a high calorie diet is a diet containing total 1000 kcal.
  • This meal should derive approximately 150, 250, and 500-600 calories from protein, carbohydrate, and fat, respectively

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diet should contain 400 kcal from carbohydrates: Incorrect. While carbohydrates are a part of the diet, this specific statement does not match the FDA's guideline for a high-fat diet.

 

Option C. Diet should contain 800 kcal from fat: Incorrect. A high-fat diet typically derives around 500-600 kcal from fat, not 800 kcal.

 

Option D. Diet should contain 80% fats: Incorrect. A high-fat diet is defined by having around 50% of its caloric content from fats, not 80%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The FDA defines a high-fat diet as one that has around 50% of its total caloric intake from fats, and a high-calorie diet should contain a total of 1000 kcal.

choices.text: The patient should undergo another point-of-care diagnostic test for the same clinical condition.
There is a 2% prevalence of the disease in the population.
It is less likely that the patient has the disease.
The patient has been mistakenly ruled out due to a false negative result.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of persistent fatigue. The physician is concerned about a particular condition and orders an on-site diagnostic test to evaluate further. The test, known to have a sensitivity of 98%, returns a negative result. Based on the high sensitivity, what is the most likely implication of this negative test outcome for the patient? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) It is less likely that the patient has the disease. 

 

  • A negative result in a diagnostic test with a sensitivity of 98% implies that the patient is less likely to have the disease.
  • Sensitivity is the proportion of all people with the disease who test positive.
  • It is the probability of the test being positive when the disease is present.
  • The sensitivity of a test is given by those who have the disease and test positive (true positives) out of the total diseased population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The patient should undergo another point-of-care diagnostic test for the same clinical condition: The patient would not need another point-of-care diagnostic test for the same clinical condition as the sensitivity of the diagnostic test is 98%.

 

Option B. There is a 2% prevalence of the disease in the population: Prevalence refers to the number of old and new cases at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It cannot be derived from the given data.

 

Option D. The patient has been mistakenly ruled out due to a false negative result: The higher the sensitivity of a diagnostic test, the lower will be the number of false negatives. Since the test has a 98% sensitivity, the patient most likely does not have the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A negative result in a highly sensitive test (98% sensitivity) makes it very unlikely that the patient has the disease, as false negatives are rare with such tests.

questions.text:
PQLI indicators include: [NEET PG 2024]

 

  1. Literacy rate
  2. Infant mortality rate
  3. Life expectancy at birth
  4. Income per capita
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Only two of these

 

The Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) is a measure used to assess the quality of life in different countries. It focuses on three main indicators: health, education, and living standards. Specifically, these indicators include:

 

1. Literacy Rate (Education): This measures the education level within a population and is included in the PQLI.

 

2. Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) (Living Standards): This measures the number of infants who die before reaching one year of age, reflecting living conditions and healthcare quality. It is included in the PQLI.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Life Expectancy at Birth: This is not included in the PQLI; instead, PQLI considers life expectancy at age one.

 

4. Income per Capita: This is not part of the PQLI; income measurements are used in the Human Development Index (HDI) but not in PQLI.

 

Thus, only the literacy rate and infant mortality rate are included in the PQLI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PQLI measures the quality of life based on literacy rate, infant mortality rate, and life expectancy at age one, excluding income and life expectancy at birth.

 

Remember – PQLI range – 0 – 100 (India - 65)

Increase in CRP leads to increased risk of MI/Stroke

questions.text: Dose for a new drug is assessed in which phase of Clinical trial? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Phase 1

 

Phase 1: This phase involves testing the drug on a small number of healthy human volunteers. The primary objective is to evaluate the drug's safety profile, non-toxicity, and determine the appropriate dosage range. Maximum tolerated dose (MTD) is often calculated in this phase, which makes it crucial for dose assessment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phase 2: Phase 2 clinical trials are designed to assess the efficacy of a drug or treatment. These trials involve a larger group of participants (100) than Phase 1 and aim to provide preliminary data on whether the drug works in people who have a certain condition or disease. Phase 2 trials also continue to monitor the drug's safety and side effects.

 

Option C. Phase 3: Phase 3 trials are conducted on a larger scale to confirm the drug's efficacy, monitor side effects, compare it to commonly used treatments, and collect information that will allow the drug to be used safely. These trials involve a larger number of participants and provide the critical data needed for regulatory approval. Drugs launched post this phase.

 

Option D. Phase 4: Phase 4 trials occur after the drug has been approved for use by the FDA. These post-marketing studies monitor the long-term effectiveness and impact on the general population, including any rare or long-term side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Ingestion of contaminated food and water

questions.text: A 45-year-old male worker presents to the emergency room with abdominal pain, irritability, fatigue, and memory problems. He works in a battery manufacturing factory for the last 20 years. On further investigations, he is diagnosed with lead poisoning. Which of the following is the most frequent mode of inorganic lead absorption contributing to his condition in such industrial environments? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Inhaled lead dust

 

  • In industrial environments such as battery manufacturing factories, the most frequent mode of inorganic lead absorption is through inhalation of lead dust.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lead Poisoning is known as ‘Plumbism’, Saturnism or Painter’s Colic

 

  • Greatest source of lead in Lead Poisoning (Plumbism, Saturnism or Painter’s Colic) is Gasoline/petrol/vehicular exhaust/automobile exhaust
  • Mode of absorption: Lead can be absorbed by inhalation (most common mode), ingestion or through skin

 

Additional Information

 

Clinical picture of lead poisoning:

 

  • Facial pallor: Earliest and most consistent sign
  • Anemia: Microcytic hypochromic
  • Punctate basophilia or basophilic stippling of RBCs
  • Burtonian Line: Lead sulphide line on gums (upper jaw)
  • Lead colic: Constipation (but sometimes diarrhea)
  • Lead Palsy (Peripheral neuropathy): Wrist drop or Foot drop
  • Lead encephalopathy
  • CNS effects: mostly due to organic lead compounds

 

Diagnosis of lead poisoning:

 

 

A useful screening test is Coproporphyrin in Urine (CPU).

 

Treatment: EDTA

The mother mentions that the child received the initial DPT vaccine dose at 6 weeks but has not received any subsequent vaccinations. What would be the most appropriate next step in this child's immunization schedule? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:

Age Limits for Delayed Immunization in NIS, India

questions.text:
Which of the provided options align with the depicted equivalence margin graph? [INICET MAY 2021]

 

 

  1. ‘A’ represents superiority of new treatment
  2. ‘I’ represents Inferiority of new treatment
  3. ‘E’ represents Non-inferior treatment
  4. ‘C’ is inconclusive
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 1, 2 and 3 

 

There are three types of comparators in Randomised Control Trials:

 

1. Superiority Trial – New drug is Better than old drug

 

2. Non-Inferiority Trial – New drug as good as old drug

 

3. Equivalence – New drug same as old drug

 

 

Other Option:

 

4. 'C' is inconclusive: This statement is incorrect as per the image. 'C' represents a superior treatment, as it falls well into the "new treatment better" region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In equivalence margin graphs for RCTs, 'A' can indicate a superior treatment, 'I' an inferior treatment, and 'E' a non-inferior treatment. 'C' does not represent an inconclusive result; it represents superiority.

choices.text: Wait until TB culture results to start ATT

questions.text: A 35-year-old homeless man presented with a 1-month history of fever, cough, and weight loss. Both sputum smears turned out to be negative, but the chest x-ray ordered was suggestive of tuberculosis. According to the recent NTEP guidelines, which is the next best line of management? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Ask for CBNAAT

 

According to the National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) guidelines, the next step in managing a patient with a high clinical suspicion of tuberculosis (TB), a suggestive chest x-ray, and negative sputum smears is to perform a CBNAAT (Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test). CBNAAT is a molecular test that detects the DNA of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and can also identify rifampicin resistance, providing rapid and accurate results.

 

DIAGNOSTIC TESTS UNDER NTEP:

 

1. Sputum smear Microscopy

  • ZN staining
  • LED – FM

 

2. Culture

 

  • LJ Medium
  • Automated Liquid culture (ALC)
    •  BACTEC MGIT 960
    • BACTALERT
    • VERSATREK

 

3. Drug sensitivity testing

 

  • Moderate Proportionate Sensitivity testing PST MGiT 960
  • Economic proportionate sensitivity testing 1% LJ Medium

 

4. Molecular Diagnosis test:

  • Line Probe Assay
    • LPA TB
    • PL LPA– INH & Rifampicin Resistance
    • SL LPA-FQ / SLI Resistance
    • NAAT
    • CBNAAT
    • True NAT True NAT
  • Developed by ICMR Real time PCR Technology 
    • True NAT MTB- MTB
    • True NAT MTB plus- MTB
    • True NAT MTB Dx- Rifampicin Resistance TEP:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeat sputum smears: Is not appropriate since the patient already had two negative sputum smears and a chest x-ray suggestive of tuberculosis.

 

Option C. CBNAAT: Should be performed first than Line probe assay.

 

Option D. TB: Culture takes time to yield results, the patient may deteriorate in the meantime.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: In a population with low prevalence of the disease, positive result with a highly sensitive test means true positive
Sensitivity depends on prevalence of the disease
Positive predictive value depends on prevalence of disease
Specificity depends on prevalence of the disease

questions.text: Among the following options, which statement accurately represents the relationship between prevalence of a disease and characteristics of a diagnostic test? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Positive predictive value depends on prevalence of disease

 

  • The accuracy of a screening test's positive predictive value (PP) relies on the disease's prevalence.
  • PPV, which stands for positive predictive value, signifies the chance that a patient showing a positive test outcome has indeed acquired the disease.
  • In other words, it represents the probability that an individual with a positive test result genuinely possesses the disease.

 

PPV of a screening test depends on:

 

  • Sensitivity
  • Specificity
  • Prevalence of disease in the population

 

PPV of a screening test is directly proportional to the prevalence of disease in the population

 

  • PPV α Prevalence of disease
  • As the prevalence of a disease increases in a population, PPV increases for the screening test

 

Sensitivity and Specificity are independent of the prevalence the of disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. In a population with low prevalence of the disease, positive result with a highly sensitive test means true positive: This is misleading because in populations with a low prevalence, a positive result from even a highly sensitive test could still be a false positive due to the low likelihood of the disease.

 

Option B. Sensitivity depends on prevalence of the disease and Option D. Specificity depends on prevalence of the disease Sensitivity and specificity are intrinsic characteristics of a test that are determined by comparing the test results against a gold standard and are independent of disease prevalence in the population being tested. They remain constant regardless of how common or rare the disease is within that group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The positive predictive value (PPV) of a diagnostic test is significantly influenced by the prevalence of the disease within the population.
  • PPV indicates the probability that individuals who test positive actually have the disease.

questions.text:
A woman presents to a clinic with her son, Ram, who has developed symptoms consistent with Measles, including fever and rash. She mentions that Ram's brother, Shyam, exhibited similar symptoms a few days earlier. Which of the following statements regarding the situation are accurate? [INICET MAY 2022]

 

  1. Ram is the index case
  2. Shyam is primary case
  3. Ram got infected from Shyam
  4. If mother had reported when Shyam got infection, Ram could have been vaccinated
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) All are correct

 

Index case: The first case that comes to the notice of the investigator. In this situation, Ram is the index case as he is the one presented to the clinic first.

 

Primary case: The first case of a disease in a population. Shyam, who exhibited symptoms a few days earlier, is the primary case.

 

Transmission: Given the incubation period of measles (7 to 18 days), it is likely that Ram got infected from Shyam, who was in an infectious state.

 

Post-exposure prophylaxis: If the mother had reported Shyam's infection, Ram could have received post-exposure prophylaxis. This can be in the form of a measles vaccine within 72 hours of exposure or immunoglobulin up to 6 days post-exposure.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Index case → First case that comes to the notice of investigator.
  • Primary case → First case of a disease in a population.
  • Incubation period of measles infection is 7 to 18 days
  • Vaccine can be given within 72 hours of post-exposure and immunoglobulin can be given up to 6 days’ post-exposure.
